issue.title: The NUnit 3 breaks integration with the TeamCity

milestone.title: Closed Without Action
milestone.description: This milestone contains closed issues where no action was taken. This includes questions, issues that could not be reproduced, rejected ideas, invalid issues, etc.

issue.body:
As you probably know, TeamCity has pretty decent integration with NUnit, and this year we released a version which integrates with NUnit3 beta. Unfortunately, after recent release of NUnit3 beta 5 our integration is no longer working. While this is understandable risk, when you're providing an integration with beta version of some tool, still we think that some problems could be easily removed. Also beta in the name usually means the tool will not change much, as it is going to be released really soon. Sadly this was not the case here. So, speaking about our problems:

1) First and foremost - NUnit still does not have proper ways to detect its version. We propose to add -version argument or some similar approach. We're aware that nunit-console.exe started without arguments will output version, but what if you change this in the future versions? Is it reliable? Clear approach to versioning will allow vendors, who integrate with the tool, at least to fail gracefully providing user friendly error messages.

2) NUnit 3 beta 5 removed filtering of tests by categories. Corresponding command line arguments were replaced with -where. Given that previous versions of NUnit3 supported these arguments, and we already released a version which works with these versions, we had to workaround this problem with proper using of -where. This sounds like not a big deal, but -where argument has not been supported by previous versions, so now we have to detect the version of the tool, see point 1. 

3) Parallel tests are now on by default. For us, it looks like a dangerous approach, which potentially can cause unnecessary problems to users. Users who did not have any problems with performance can face instability problems with tests after upgrade to new NUnit. Moreover, our users (those who run tests on TeamCity build agents) often run tests on virtual machines having 1 core, and for such users it does not make much sense to enable parallelization by default. So they will not benefit from parallelization, but chances are high that they will suffer from instability problems. Currently we have to workaround this problem too, by providing --workers=1 argument by default.

4) nunit-console.exe is now called nunit3-console.exe. Well for us, those who look at the project from outside, this change does not look like justified. Sure there are some incompatibilities with command line and people will have problems with their scripts where they call nunit-console.exe directly. But, some incompatibilities, like removed filtering of tests, could be easily fixed. Others, like parallelization by default, also have issues, and could be re-thought. Also such a change raises questions about future versions. Are we going to see nunit4-console.exe soon? What about minor versions, do you plan to have nunit31-console.exe? Is this now official approach to versioning? Does it mean that people will have to fix their build scripts and CI server configuration, each time when you change executable name?

And as a general note, for vendors like us, command line arguments are like API, and as it makes sense to preserve compatibility with API, it also makes sense to preserve it with command line. Note, that we're all for new tools, new features, etc. But changes in API should be justified, and vendors and your users should have clear understanding why they need to fix their tools. And just to make our point more clear. It's not that we insist on backward compatibility, we understand that tool should evolve. It's just that sometimes, backward compatibility can be preserved with relatively small effort. And this small effort can save days or months of work of other people. It would be great if NUnit team paid a little bit more attention to compatibility issues in the future.

rename.from: User should have ability to get version (major.minor[.build[.revision]]) using nunit console
rename.to: User should have ability to get a version (major.minor[.build[.revision]]) using nunit console

rename.from: User should have ability to get a version (major.minor[.build[.revision]]) using nunit console
rename.to: It should be possible to determine version of NUnit using nunit console tool

body: So would a --version option displaying the standard two-line header work for you?
I would think a --version command would be easier to process if it returned a single line?
I think it could be like this 3.0.5784 without any other lines or text

If it's not too much trouble, I'd prefer to follow the Gnu standard for --version...
   http://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/standards.html#g_t_002d_002dversion
That makes more sense if somebody just type's it in at the command-line and isn't hard to parse.

Currently, our first two lines meet that standard:

NUnit Console Runner 3.0.5674
Copyright (C) 2015 Charlie Poole

In Debug, we add (Debug) at the end of the first line, but I could move that in front of the version so it's always at the end.

While we are doing this, we should pull the copyright from the assemblyinfo
instead of hard coding it here and in nunitlite.
On Nov 3, 2015 6:40 AM, "CharliePoole" notifications@github.com wrote:

> If it's not too much trouble, I'd prefer to follow the Gnu standard for
> --version...
> http://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/standards.html#g_t_002d_002dversion
> That makes more sense if somebody just type's it in at the command-line
> and isn't hard to parse.
> 
> Currently, our first two lines meet that standard:
> 
> NUnit Console Runner 3.0.5674
> Copyright (C) 2015 Charlie Poole
> 
> In Debug, we add (Debug) at the end of the first line, but I could move
> that in front of the version so it's always at the end.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/978#issuecomment-153327078.

We also should better define the AssemblyVersion then just "3.0.*".

Perhaps `3.<major revision>.<alpha/beta/rc number>.*`

Using 0xx for alpha, 1xx for beta, and 2xx for RC?

So the current build would be AssemblyVersion "3.0.200.*".

I've already modified some of this code for #922, so I'll take this one to avoid conflicts.

@NikolayPianikov Let me know if you're OK with what I proposed above. I'll start working on that basis, with --version and -v giving the two line output. If you strongly prefer to have just the number, we could do that as well.

issue.title: Add version option to console and nunitlite. Fixes #978
issue.body:
First shot at fixing #978. I'd like @NikolayPianikov to review in addition to at least one of the committers, since he's the one who asked for it. :-)

Particular questions... 
1. Should I further change the format to move the (Debug) in front of the version so the first line reads like...
   NUnit Console Runner (Debug) 3.0.1234
2. I did the same thing with NUnitLite. NUnitLite also shows some stuff in parentheses after the version, even in release. If I move the parenthesized stuff for console, I'll do the same for NUnitLite.
3. In addition to --version | -V I can add some special, long option just for use by CI programs if it's really needed... something like --version-number perhaps.

body: I think I can parse suggested text. The main thing this format should be stable from version to version. Thank you

Great! We'll go ahead after I fix the items that came out in the review.

I think you can count on the first or only match for a three-component version number in the first line always being what you want. You are probably even safe to take the first instance of '2' or '3' as your guide, but that's a little loose.
